Masterpiece biopic covering the life of boxer, Jake Le Motta, from his triumph to downfall.  Robert De Niro gives the performance of his life as Le Motta, transforming from a lean, furious fighter to a drunk has been who sees his life fall apart.  He gets great support from the rest of the cast, especially Joe Pesci has much abused brother/manager.  Behind the camera, director Martin Scorsese delivers one of his best films, who despite not being a boxing fan, delivers one of the best films about the subject ever.  The fights are expertly filmed, especially with the use of animal noises to emphasize the mentalities of the fighters.  The black and white look also gives a nice, documentary feel to it.  Overall, one of the best films by the two giants ever.

Giacobbe "Jake" LaMotta (Robert De Niro) is never actually called "Raging Bull" in the film, but there couldn't be a better nickname for the middleweight boxer in describing his personality both in and outside the ring. The sports actually in sports movies are usually pretty poor and the story typically has much more to do with the lives of the characters and their broader impact on the culture, but boxing seems to be an exception, as it is one of the most exciting, intimate, and enjoyable sports to capture in a dramatic film. In black & white, Scorsese puts forth a brutal movie from start to finish where you expect some of this sweat and bloodshed to act as a release for the irascible and uncontainable LaMotta. It's the 1940s and 50s at the height of the urban Italian stereotype — think arguments from window to the street, guinea tees, crucifixes hanging on walls, and domestic abuse. Everyone, all the time, seems to be yelling and pushing and threatening each other with LaMotta at the nucleus of it all. Perfectly De Niro, LaMotta goes from jocular to irate as he hectors his brother, Joey (Joe Pesci) to punch him in the face. It's a biopic without the typical biopic arc. Sure, he ditches the woman (Lori Anne Flax) he's initially with for a new one, but besides that, it's an up-and-down of athletic success, alienating family without reconciliation, and ultimately rock-bottom without redemption. The camera work in the second Sugar Ray Robinson (Johnny Barnes) scene and the final soliloquy are iconic.

If my expectations weren't so high, maybe I would give it four stars but maybe not.  It's definitely not a five star movie in my opinion.

This film, made in 1980 starring Jake LaMotta played by Robert De Niro and Joe Pesci as Joey. The story was written by Jake LaMotta, Joseph Carter and Peter Savage. The story follows a middleweight boxer also known as the Bronx Bull, during his professional career as well as his life outside of the ring. The film is black and white in order to replicate the time it took place between 1941 to the mid 1950's. Based in the Bronx, Jake's main goal remains at earning the title in his career as a professional fighter. All the while he ruins his life outside of his career and holds boxing above all else. He will do whatever it takes in order to get to the top without regard for his wife and child. Jake has a very violent demeanor that really affects many of the relationships in his life including his second wife Vickie LaMotta. This film portrayed the level of violence that was present during this time and how women were being treated by men who had superior levels of aggression when things didn't necessarily go the way they wanted them to. His levels of aggression then spiral to him being obsessively jealous towards Vickie and any sort of interaction she has with anyone which more often than not turns physical. After losing a fight and everything else he felt he had, it wasn't until two years later he was able to fight for the title spot against Marcel Cerdan. The jealousy with Vickey continues to tear apart not only Jake's marriage but his relationship with Joey as well. His level of anger becomes such a problem that it affects every aspect of his life. The following six years Jake retired and moved to Florida with Vicky and his three children after also gaining weight following his boxing career. He soon gets involved with underage girls and destroys his championship belt in order to gain money for his legal fees.The film wraps up with Jake seeing Joey again after years have passed and still Joey has anger towards all that Jake has done to him. Jake talking to himself in the mirror before a show, shows that men like Jake who have made all of these mistakes in their life can change and make their future better than it was and move on from their past choices and decisions. This film was an accurate representation of the time period and the forces that drove people like Jake to make bad decisions in their life outside of their work. You can tell by the way Jake acted affected everyone around him just by his presence and demeanor. He was able to find himself toward the end of the film and come to the realization that there was more to life than just boxing.

Raging Bull Film Review
The film Raging Bull was directed by Martin Scorcese and produced by Robert Chartoff and Irvin Winkler.  The main characters were portrayed by Robert DeNiro, Catherine Moriarty, and Joe Pesci.  The films follows the story of Jake LaMotta, a middleweight boxer who's climb to the top in boxing leads to a spiraling downfall outside of the ring. Not only is the character of Jake LaMotta violent inside the ring, he is equally violent to his wives, neighbors, and ultimately his brother.  This ultimately leads to two divorces, an estrangement with his brother, and ultimately some jail time.  At the end of the film, he ends up doing stand-up comedy in a tiny nightclub.  The film was done in black and white to be authentic with the time (1940s), and the film score has a dramatic sad tone to it.  I would recommend this film for mature adults due to the intensity that the actors portray brilliantly.  DeNiro especially is thoroughly believable as a boxing star with a very violent nature.  Given the film's violent nature and constant profanity, the R rating is appropriate.

When Martin Scorsese accepted his Oscar, many of his fans felt a mixture of relief and disappointment. Oscar sticks a needle in the flesh, but it hurts just a little, whereas Scorsese cuts it; Oscar is redemption, Scorsese is dissection. Two different things. So, with "Raging Bull," the Oscars can honor De Niro's heat and reject Scorsese's cold. 

 Jake LaMotta, the middleweight boxing champion of the world in 1949, wrote an autobiography dissecting his life. De Niro recommended it to Scorsese, and the souls of three Italian-born New Yorkers resonated. At a time when Scorsese was troubled, addicted, divorced and on the verge of bankruptcy, reading the autobiography was like finding an outlet. 

 La Motta fought his way up, very smoothly, the fist to the flesh of the scene in Scorsese's rapid editing is extremely tension, in order not to let the audience pay too much attention to the violence, had to change the color of the whole film to black and white. La Motta is a man who believes in using his fists, so when he complains that his hands are too small for a heavyweight, the sadness is genuine. 

 Even if he made a mistake, for the sake of his future and the triad compromise a fake fist fight, but in the break room to cry on the head or let us forgive him. What is a good man, made a mistake, corrected, is a good man. Success takes a price, and when La Motta, with the world boxing belt on his back, went to the corner to console the loser, it was like watching a movie. 

 Boxing is not a place to stay, and La Motta's departure confirms Hemingway's dictation: You can be destroyed, but you cannot be knocked down. There he was at the side of the ring bleeding from the nose, refusing to go down, swearing, just like old beauty always does. But fortunately, he still accepted, more mixed worse does not matter, first his own nightclub, and then to work as a stand-up clown, did not see how he lost. 

 The year 1980 is not far from now, and even if the movie were about the 1940s, it would make a lot of sense for an "up-and-coming" man to beat his wife, even from a "non-feminist" perspective. Even if Vicky's kisses are a little flirty, La Motta's vinegar-eating is pretty headshaking. 

 Well, if it is not petty, then La Motta must be thinking something wrong. The more he is obsessed with Vicky the more paranoid he is, the more he is obsessed with boxing the more he is obsessed with losing, the more he is obsessed with sensuality the more he is empty. Lamotta lost himself in the pressure of fame and fortune, and beating his wife was just one of the outward manifestations. 

 There is no way back, can only carry forward, this is the life is not complete. Such a person, we can sympathize with but not completely sympathize with, hate also cannot hate completely. The kind of heroes and villains that are so familiar in movies are all gone, blended into a La Motta and a real person. 

 No one is perfect. Every character makes mistakes. People who do not make mistakes cannot be trusted. It is like when La Motta went to jail and banged his head against the wall, it is like masochism, but it is not really a confession, it is a way to make sure I am not a jerk. So, no matter how gray, this movie still has a positive point. Everyone who has a dream will have a desire on their back; Every effort, behind is the struggle. We all know Raging Bull exceeded expectations when we realize what the expectations were beforehand. The idea of the film came from Robert DeNiro who plays Jake LaMotta, a 1940's and 50's boxer who seems to be completely insecure about himself as a whole. Directed by Martin Scorsese, produced by Robert Chartoff, and written by Mardik Martin, the film unravels the life of one of the best fighters of all time. Before the film was considered for production, DeNiro had a rough time convincing Scorsese to be the director. However, eventually he found light when Chartoff said he'll produce it if Scorsese agrees to direct it. Scorsese almost dies from a drug overdose, leading him to a change of heart and a desire to make the film, eventually saving his own career and life. Raging Bull depicts the life of Jake LaMotta through moments in the ring and moments in life. The moments in life always trailed into the ring, because Jake experienced so many instances of insecurity whether it was women, family or moments of doubt within himself. He took everything out on his opponents and the ones around him. Moments like when he finally attains the unattainable, his wife Vicky. Jake marries Vicky, but then sees her as a slut after she sleeps with him. Why? He has a mind complex that any female who's not a virgin, is a whore. The instances in the movie where this is depicted are truly beautiful, because they're shot and done so well. Scorsese portrays the anger and frustration of LaMotta through facial expressions and emotions when he feels insecure about his relationship with Vicky. LaMotta believes that his own wife would be happier sleeping with other people rather than him, he eventually confronts her about sleeping with his brother. Completely outrageous. Jake was known as a vicious fighter in the ring, which came from his anger outside of the ring. But the movie never really delved deep into the fighting itself, its was a film about the boxer himself and his inability to conquer jealousy and insecurity. LaMotta fights himself for most of the movie, and in the end he comes to a realization that all the trouble he's caused is nobody else's fault. The production was a masterpiece in my opinion, every emotion was clear and brilliantly portrayed, from Jake's emotions to his wife's and even the other boxers, who were deathly afraid in the ring at times due to the viciousness in LaMotta's eyes. 

9/10. I had to get myself to like the movie, because I love sports and fighting movies are awesome, but it wasn't necessarily about the fighting itself. The movie took me on a journey, watching a character break himself down and learn how badly it hurt him in the end.

Raging Bull is a sports biopic directed by Martin Charles Scorsese in 1980. Robert Anthony De Niro Jr, who plays the leading role in this film, also won the Oscar for best actor.
The final subtitle of the film quotes a sentence in the Gospel of John, "All I know is this: Once I was blind and now I can see" This also summarizes the plot of the film. Young Jake is a boxer. He is invincible in the challenge arena, but he never qualified for the championship. He thinks he is unwilling to compromise with the mafia. Later, he married and had children, but because he could not play the championship, he became increasingly decadent. Later, because of his incompetence in reality, he became more and more angry. His life with his wife gradually collapsed, and even because he suspected his brother and wife, he fought against his brother, causing the two brothers to break up. One day, he was finally willing to compromise and won the championship he dreamed of. In the days that followed, Jake, who experienced many joys and sorrows, worked as a talk show actor in the bar and spent the rest of his life in this way.
This film is a very classic one. First of all, it uses black and white pictures, because the director Martin Scorsese believes that color film will fade after a long time. In order to make the film never fade, he simply uses black and white pictures at the beginning. The second reason is that he thinks the red boxing gloves are too conspicuous. The focus of this film is eight boxing matches, which is the turning point in the plot and also the turning point of Jake's fate. In addition, the boxing match itself is also an audio-visual feast. He doesn't want to be too eye-catching. In addition, some other technologies used in the film are also epoch-making. First, the camera revolved around the site and glided, which was quite novel in those days. The montage technique is used in the sound effect processing of the film. In the boxing match, strange howls and lightning are often mixed, jumping into silence and returning to reality, enriching the performance level of the film. After I watched the film, I thought the character Jake in the play made me very anxious and angry. I knew he was not a bad man, but I just couldn't sympathize with him.
In a word, the pictures, sound effects and clips of this film were later widely used as teaching materials. It is precisely because of the birth of such a good film that it can bring more inspiration to film lovers later, and also promote the emergence of more outstanding films later.

Written by Jake LaMotta, Raging Bull was adapted and directed by Martin Scorsese. The film was produced by Irwin Winkler and Robert Chartoff and starred the incredibly talented Robert De Niro. The film grossed nearly twenty-three and a half million dollars. 

The story opens with a washed-up 1964 Jake LaMotta reciting lines in his dressing room about his glory days. Suddenly we are back to 1941, where Jake is getting pummeled in the ring. It looks like it will take a miracle for LaMotta to make it out of this fight, and yet less than a minute later, after a flurry of punches, his opponent is lifeless on the canvas. Still, after a rigged decision from the committee, Jake is down and out, losing the fight by unanimous decision. Later, we see Jake verbally assaulting his wife Irma and are let into this darker side of LaMotta's personality. His rage in the ring does not stop once he leaves but instead haunts him everywhere he goes. We see the further maltreatment of his wife as he pursues a young girl named Vickie, who turns out to be the cause of much conflict throughout the film. Jake's insecurities about his relationship with Vickie destroy many necessary relationships within his life. Tommy and Salvy try to help Jake get a title fight, but they part ways following a fight between Joey and them over Vickie.
Further into the movie, Jake becomes accusatory of Vickie, claiming she had an affair with Salvy and even his brother Joey. The fight that follows between him and Joey completely breaks the brother's relationship, and although Jake follows this up by punching Vickie, she agrees to stay with him. Showing how back then, the abuse and mistreatment of women was something that went unchecked. It is a weird thing to see on screen when we know how much has changed in today's society. I think the film does a good job touching on social issues at the time, mainly because LaMotta was involved with all walks of life. The style of the film leaves you wanting more, and the abrupt changes keep your eyes glued to the film. I would strongly recommend this to any fans of Scorsese or De Niro, especially boxing fans. I think the movie is very well put together and would say the choices made by the director and, obviously, De Niro brings this story to life.

While Raging Bull is often considered to be one of the best films ever made, and Scorsese's best collaboration with Robert De Niro, ultimately this film fell a bit flat with me. Perhaps I have been spoilt by the later works of Scorsese, but while the performance of De Niro was strong and the film was shot beautifully, I just felt no connection with this story and it struggled to hold my attention. I am also a product of a different generation, where boxing is mainly oversaturated in films rather than a popular and highly valued American sport. Maybe if I hadn't seen films such as Rocky, Creed, and The Fighter, I'd have been more enticed to learn more about Jake LaMotta's story but I found it wholly uninteresting. Given its status as such a highly regarded classic in film, I also went in with pretty high expectations. These were met in the technical aspects of the film – Scorcese's direction, Thelma Schoonmaker's editing, Michael Chapman's cinematography, production design, and De Niro's main role all excel in every way. Still, I struggled to engage or care with the material that was so well dressed by these masters of craft – which could very much just be a personal problem.
	Jake LaMotta is not intended to be a sympathetic, heroic, or charismatic main character. The story of Raging Bull is one of self-destruction, as Jake LaMotta refuses to ever let himself live a nice life. The boxing matches are more compelling than the personal matters that drag on throughout the duration and slowly fester until LaMotta is left all alone and no longer has boxing. The events and drama seem to blur into one, providing little reason to become emotionally invested in any of the characters who don't seem to grow, change, or behave in any way that entices viewers to watch events unfold. There doesn't seem to be any sort of satisfaction is seeing LaMotta end up exactly where he deserves to be, which I might attribute to writing or perhaps the risk of creating a biographical drama on a real person. The depiction might possibly lose meaning in its endeavor to be true to LaMotta. Overall, I can see why this is a great film, but I feel it is bogged down in a lackluster story and little characterization. I would sooner rewatch other Scorsese films that handle the aforementioned aspects of film better and are equally excellent in their technical accomplishments.

Scorsese's First K.O.

Martine Scorsese is one of the best directors at sympathizing agonized and tortured characters to viewers and Raging Bull is a perfect example of this genius. Scorsese, who just before making the film suffered from a cocaine overdose, could resonate with Jake LaMotta, a boxer with self-destructive tendencies. Robert DeNiro, who plays Jake LaMotta, and Martin Scorsese developed a bond that started in this movie and has continued to this day. In the movie, Jake LaMotta (Robert DeNiro) is a boxer in the 1980's who uses his rage and destructive tendencies in the boxing ring, but also in his relationships with love interest Vickie, played by Cathy Moriarty. He is constantly jealous and insecure that Vickie is interested in other men and the viewers can see his rage control him as he pours it out on his opponents in and out of the ring. Another big name in the film is Joe Pesci, who plays Joey LaMotta, Jake's brother and manager. Jake and Joey eventually come to blows as Jake suspects Joey of having relations with Vickie. A major theme throughout the movie is the self-destructive tendencies of a man who is plagued by insecurities of jealousy and rage. Time and time again, Jake LaMotta is his own worst enemy as he burns bridges and pours out his rage on people who care about him the most. Even though Jake is a character that people should despise, Scorsese has a talent of sympathizing the character throughout the movie. There are times that the viewers can see the torment that Jake LaMotta experiences and it is seen that he understands that he has self-destructive tendencies. The film forces the viewers to understand the ramifications of when individuals become their own worst enemy and does so in an extreme manner of rage and violence in the boxing ring. The film did not initially make shockwaves in the box office, however it was nominated for multiple awards and won multiple Academy awards. This film was a huge boost for Scorsese's career and years after he is one of the most famous directors, it is easy to look back at one of his first successful films and see his brush strokes on an early masterpiece.

He does not back down to anyone in the ring and even to those in his life. His path to greatness is encouraged by his brother Joey. Joey's encouragement as well as the encouragement of his close friends and love one is the reason why Jake is so demanding and does not take disappointment well. He tends to rage when he thinks he is being challenged hence the title of the movie. While the film is supposed to be centered on Jake, Joey is another stand out character for this unyielding loyalty for his brother even in spite of his knowing Jake was being "bull- headed". 
In my opinion if you want to see a movie that is heavily based on siblings and an endless amount of encouragement this is the movie for you. If you don't mind a bit of gorge and a lot of internal battles this movie is also for you. The film has moments of close ups that makes you feel that you are immersed in the ring with Jake when he fights. These moments of close ups make the movie much more thrilling and keeps your attention throughout. I would recommend this movie not only for the story line but for the great acting done by Robert De Niro. He makes the scenes come to life with every punch he throws and towards the end of the film he shows a side of Jake LaMotta that make you feel that you had no idea who he really was in his life. There are moments in the film where Martin Scorsese signature filming technique of applying slow motion at the right time causes the viewer to take in every bit of the scene and feel the significant of that particular moment. With great directing and great acting this 2 hour film will not disappoint.

Raging Bull is a 1980's movie based on the book and life of Jake La Motta (Robert De Niro) himself. It follows the story of his rise to fame and recognition in the boxing world as well as his demons in his own personal life. The director of the film was Martin Scorsese who was up and coming at the time, featuring actors such as Robert De Niro, Joe Pesci, and Cathy Moriarty. I feel like most of the cinematography was standard for that time, but one part that stood out was the 2nd fight with Sugar Ray Leonard where Jake was standing against the ropes and just letting Sunny pound on him telling him he never put him on the mat. During this scene, they did a Point of View (POV) of Sunny from Jake's perspective as he is swinging on him with the distorted background. 
The directors were good at catching the big moments in the film where they wanted to drive home raw human emotion such as when Jake attacks his brother Joey (Joe Pesci). We also see the struggles of up-and-coming fighters at the time with the crime families having such a pull in how fights were set up and who got the shot at the title. Jake wanted nothing to do with them, but without their help, he understood he would be stuck, also coming to terms with never being in the heavyweight division due to his size. I love the fact we can flash forward and see the extended effect of crime families on boxing and how they recruited people from tough upbringings and shape them into who they wanted. This can be seen later in the 1960s when Sonny Liston becomes heavyweight champion and had ties with the mob as an enforcer. 
My overall rating of this movie is a 4 out of 5 stars, I would recommend this to someone who was a sports history fan or likes dramas from the 1940s. You can see how traditional roles were treated for men and women with how the interactions between Jake and his wife Vickie (Cathy Moriarty). In conclusion, this was an interesting film between the sports aspect of a professional who was trying to reach the top without anyone else's help, and his waxing poetic later on as he comes to a realization of reaching the end of his career. His ups and downs gave him perspective on life and to not take everything he had for granted which was symbolized by the ending quote for the movie.

Watching "Raging Bull," I found myself strangely reminded of "Citizen Kane," eventually realizing why: like Kane, the true star of "Raging Bull" and quite possibly the key to its consistent acclaim is its bold, brash and highly innovative editing style. Surely, it can be convincingly argued that "Raging Bull" is a masterwork in terms of the heightened dramatization of its subject matter which is achieved through the sheer force of editing alone. At the same time, we observe an inherently compelling concept at the root of its theme; namely the shocking captivity of one man to the pathology of his own anger, paranoia, and self-loathing. There is an operatic quality to the fight sequences which is intermittently brutal and quietly cathartic, achieving unexpected moments of almost transcendent elegance. All strengths considered, I must attest to coming away from the film feeling slightly underwhelmed by its characters. More particularly, in La Motta we're shown a bestial entity perpetually engaged in self-purification through expressions of anger, yet we're offered no insight into the source of that rage. He is merely a brute without the benefit of any additional dimensions to round him out and engage our interest or understanding. For such reasons, I'm slightly shocked to see "Raging Bull" so consistently proclaimed as one of the greatest films of all time; it most assuredly is not. It is, however, a bold, ambitious, and ultimately unforgettable depiction of the poetry of the boxing ring enacted within one man's turbulent spirit and expressed through the most merciless eloquence of his fists.

Director Martin Scorsese's sports biographical drama Raging Bull (1980) is a fearsome picture from Scorsese about an unlikable man named Jake LaMotta, who went from legit boxing legend to pathetic comedy stand-up doing cringe-inducing jokes in little nightclubs. Scorsese gives you the man's home life flux and boxing career highlights with a visceral, dreamy directorial style all his own. No one directs like Scorsese and Raging Bull is some of his finest and sharpest filmmaking.

Writers Paul Schrader and Mardik Martin allow you into the troubled mind of a hopeful boxer with a cruel punching method of wearing down his opponents with vicious hits, while he himself gets clobbered mercilessly. Raging Bull is not about the boxing matches, but about how long they went on and with what brutality this bloodsport contains, much like Jake LaMotta's own life of bullying and violence. Raging Bull is all about Jake LaMotta's fiercely combative personality that ruins his life rather than his cruel boxing style. Meanwhile, composer Pietro Mascagni delivers only beauty with his entrancing symphonic score that is romantic, epic, and sincere. Mascagni's melodies soar above all the blood and bruises, adding an elegance to Scorsese's Raging Bull.

Scorsese's direction is impeccable with a stellar creativity in filming each boxing sequence like it's a magic show or something. Unique angles, panning shots, and long held close-ups ensures Raging Bull stays with you with a gorgeous black and white aesthetic that still shows all the sweat and blood. Michael Chapman's cinematography has all these wonderful shots from the zoom out on Sugar Ray Chapman surrounded by smoke in an ethereal first person shot from Jake's perspective to Vicki splashing her feet in a local pool to show her underage youth and playful personality. 

Thelma Schoonmaker's first collaboration with Martin Scorsese starts with Raging Bull and her cuts are so sharp and entertaining. From Jake needing a punch in the face to Thelma cutting to him getting beaten in a boxing match and so forth with her effortlessly clever cuts to her steady pacing that keeps Raging Bull's 129 rush by like a knockout punch!

Scorsese sympathizes with this lumbering brute and all his inner turmoil, constant doubt, increasing paranoia, endless jealousy, brutal violence, and cruel domestic abuse with a fair and balanced direction for Raging Bull. You see Jake LaMotta's fearsome rage in every word, glare, and punch of Robert De Niro's leading role. De Niro captures Jake LaMotta's flurry of swift punishing punches, brutal manner, distrusting nature, disgusting sexism, commanding gravitas, cringe humor, and fearful paranoia all with ease. He's easy to hate and difficult to understand, but Scorsese lets you witness LaMotta's boxing glory days to his embarrassing low moments in one of Scorsese's greatest pictures: Raging Bull.

Joe Pesci steals the show as Joey LaMotta, Jake's brother and trainer, who manages to push his brother to stardom and success, all while dealing with Jake's incessant temper tantrums and vicious assaults. I love seeing Pesci go from quiet and patient to bursting with violence and righteous indignation at Jake's mean taunts and shocking violence. I appreciate how Pesci is subtle as portraying Joey's frustrations with Jake's rage with his incredulous faces and aghast expressions. 

Pesci is fascinating to watch throughout Raging Bull as Joey starts out empathetic and measured with his reassurations and pep talks to De Niro's Jake LaMotta, but you see Pesci's Joey cheating on his wife and belittling her just like how Jake treats his poor wife Vicki LaMotta as beautifully portrayed by Cathy Moriarty. She is perfect as the flirty and forlorn Vicki as she must succumb to Jake's every wish and order until she's had enough. Moriarty plays each moment with a knowing that lets you know Vicki understands every jealous question and hurtful comment made by Jake cuts deeply.

Frank Vincent is great as the two-faced goon Salvy with his compliments to Jake's face, then insults behind his back to all his friends. Nicholas Colasanto is excellent as the Godfather type mafia boss Tommy Como with his boxing demands and ever present presence in Jake's life and career. Theresa Saldana is gorgeous as Joey's wife Lenore. You feel so sorry for her just like Cathy Moriarty's Vicki as she is mistreated horribly by these wretched men. 

John Turturro cameos as a man at the same club table as Salvy and Tommy early in his acting career. Martin Scorsese's father Charles Scorsese cameos as Charlie when Tommy visits Jake in his apartment. Martin Scorsese himself has a cameo as a club stagehand later on in Raging Bull. Johnny Barnes is captivating as Sugar Ray Robinson opposite Robert De Niro's barrelling Jake LaMotta. Michael Westmore and Mike Maggi's make-up transforms De Niro into Jake LaMotta with a broader nose, torn eye gashes, beat up marks, and fat additions to capture LaMotta's weight gains and losses throughout the years. Richard Bruno, Marilyn Putnam, Robert Iannacconne, and Andrea E. Weaver's costumes fit the 1940's and 1950's eras from the boxing uniforms to the nightlife scene's tight lavish dresses and slick suits.

In all, Raging Bull is a rush of blood to the head like one of Jake LaMotta's legendary boxing bouts. Martin Scorsese at his peak technical prowess with powerful acting all over Raging Bull.

The scenes were intense it showed raging quick-tempered crowds, bar and restaurant fights and serval domestic disputes. The characters are true to their form, hot-tempered tough guys who show heavy family presence and who supported each other. The Director does a fantastic job by intensifying the emotions of this era throw the real-life events taking place. Raging Bull directed by Martin Scorsese, produced by Irwin Winkler and Robert Chartoff, and scripted by Paul Schrader, the spectacular adaptation of Jake LaMotta's memoir, focusing not only on his boxing career but also in his life before and after it won two Oscars.  

Raging Bull goes through the life and career of the boxer Jake LaMotta (Robert De Niro) who experiences up and down all his life because of his competitiveness, jealousy, anger. His goal is to become the middleweight boxer champion with the help of his brother and manager Joey LaMotta (Joe Pesci). However, fame, the mafia, and his relationship with his second wife Vickie (Cathy Moriarty) are not going to make it easy. 

The characterization of Robert De Niro as Jake LaMotta is one of the strongest highlights of the film, the changes of his physical appearance throughout the story are remarkable as he gained muscle and weight for the filming. This along with the extraordinary makeup and camera work make the fights more authentic and powerful.  

I would like to point out how other topics of the movie apart from boxing like domestic violence and uncontrolled anger are well discussed and represented. Jake LaMotta's distrust in his wife Vickie makes him be violent against her, and conditions his fights. Throughout the film, we are constantly living realistic situations in which Jake hits Vickie, Joey, or breaks down doors because of his suspicion that Vickie is sleeping with other men.  

Even though color movies were already being made, Scorsese decided to do it in black and white making it stand out from the other films, I liked that he introduced a short sequence of colored recordings when he got married to Vickie showing the few moments when he was happy and did not argue with her. He gave a lot of importance to the timeline of the story and the evolution of Jake as a person. 

As I mentioned before, the camera work is a fundamental element for the film, for example, the angle is showing the public who is dominating the fight, when Jake is asking Joey to hit him, Jake is always above Joey. In the fights in the ring, Scorsese uses long shots when the boxers are thinking and close-up shots when they are fighting, transmitting an asphyxia feeling. 

Scorsese uses other resources like sound and lighting to transmit and complement the emotions and background of the characters. For instance, the movie starts with the opera "Cavalleira Rusticana" commonly used in the genre Verismo that focused on low-class characters. However, the synchronization and the sound of the punches was slightly artificial, it did not sound realistic. 

In conclusion, I really recommend this movie, it has many hidden symbols that tell a story by themselves. It focuses much more than boxing, making it distinctive and worth seeing it.

Raging Bull is a 1980 film directed by Martin Scorsese starring Robert De Niro as Jake LaMotta, Joe Pesci as Joey, and Cathy Moriarty as Vickie LaMotta. The movie was produced by Robert Chartoff and Irwin Winkler with a screenplay written by Paul Shrader and Mardik Martin. The film is based on the book by Jake LaMotta, Joseph Carter, and Peter Savage, and tells the true story of LaMotta's life as a boxer in the 1940s and 50s. LaMotta's rage often serves him well inside the boxing ring, but he is unable to maintain the stability he craves outside of the ring due to his self-destructive tendencies. 
	Production highlights include remarkable cinematography by Michael Chapman and sound effects by sound effects supervising editor Frank Warner. Chapman's immersive camerawork takes the viewer inside the boxing ring, quickly cutting back and forth between point of view shots to match the rate of the boxer's punches. Warner's impeccable sound editing adds to the realism of Chapman's cinematography during each match. The loud punches, audience screams, and camera flashes punctuate a muted background track that sounds like a train rushing by, while rare moments of silence interrupt the heightened volume of each fight. Scorsese's decision to shoot the film in black and white adds to the film's realism as well, as boxing in the 1940s typically aired in black and white on television. Color appears in the movie only once, during a montage depicting rare moments of happiness and stability in LaMotta's personal life such as his marriage to Vicki. Unfortunately, LaMotta's jealousy and rage get in the way of the bright future he craves. 
	Robert De Niro certainly deserves the best actor Oscar he won for his portrayal of Jake LaMotta in Raging Bull. LaMotta is a complex character filled with imperfections and De Niro's exquisite portrayal allows the audience to become invested in a character with questionable morals who can't contain his fighting to the ring. De Niro's training for the role is evident in the realistic boxing scenes and his 60-pound weight gain in the second half of the film demonstrates his deep commitment to the role. 
	Overall, I highly recommend this film to all viewers, even those who are not boxing fans. The film is notable for Scorsese's excellent direction and De Niro's superb performance. Although the movie is long, the fast-paced action escalates quickly and is likely to leave viewers on the edge of their seats. 
Raging Bull is an intergenerationally relevant film due to its relatable examination of the imperfections and contradictions of the human existence. LaMotta strives to find balance between his lives in and out of the boxing ring, but at the end of the day, he is unable to get out of his own way.

Um triunfo de um filme. Scorsese teve uma longa e distinta carreira ao lado do protagonista do filme, Robert de Niro. Este filme mostra as duas lendas do cinema no seu melhor. O filme também explora muitas das questões complexas da violência contra as mulheres e da destruição psicológica de um homem que não consegue aceitar ou compreender a intimidade. A verdadeira magia é que essas questões são expressas por meio das explosões psicológicas distorcidas do personagem de De Niro. Todos ao redor de LaMotto podem ver seu problema, sua obsessão doentia e suspeita, mas ele não consegue se conter. O filme encontra sua expressão na imaturidade emocional do personagem principal. LaMotto não pode avaliar introspectivamente suas emoções. Seu processo de pensamento é infinitamente fascinante de assistir enquanto ele transforma qualquer ato de bondade ou amor em traição e distância. Ele carece de maturidade emocional ou consciência para comunicar suas frustrações em palavras. O público simplesmente observa enquanto qualquer pequeno ato ou suspeita é uma janela para ele confirmar o que ele mais deseja, a confirmação de que seu parceiro é infiel e, por extensão, ele próprio é indigno. Seu ódio é profundo, não um ódio dos outros ou do que ele ataca, mas um ódio de si mesmo. Todos ao seu redor percebem, mas LaMotto simplesmente não consegue. O filme oferece o olho para os detalhes que tornou Scorsese famoso. As cenas de luta de boxe são brilhantes e brutais. O elenco de apoio também é excelente.

One winter morning, many years ago now, I sat down to watch Raging Bull. I had seen it before and had enjoyed it. But this time was different as I was suffering hang-over guilt from an incident the night before. It was in this state of mind that I experienced the Jake La Motta (De Niro) story and gained a greater understanding of what I believe Scorsese was trying to say through this character.

Raging Bull can simply be viewed as a sports film on a par with its contemporary, Rocky. You may think it a bio-epic merely charting the life of Jake La Motta (De Niro). But no, this film digs a lot deeper, exploring themes that can be recognized universally – well, mainly by those with a Y chromosome, as the premise of the film deals with troubled male identity. This is apparent in the character of Jake La Motta and also, to a lesser extent, his bother Joey (Pesci). This is why I, sitting in a pit somewhere in England, like many flawed men, can make a personal connection with the film's anti-hero, even though it is set in the Italian ghettos of New York City in the 1940s.

The story of Raging Bull begins in the later stages of Jake La Motta's life. He stands alone in a dressing room, overweight and repulsive, a shadow of his former self, framed so as to seem cornered-in. Smash-cut to the younger Jake La Motta, again cornered-in, but this time in the boxing ring. From there on in, Scorsese begins the Jake La Motta story, bringing the audience right into his demonic world. We are taken through his boxing career, his relationships with his wife Vicky (Moriarty) and his brother Joey (Pesci). We witness his attempts at night club management and then as a stand-up comic. Jake fails at everything, his spiral downwards portrayed so brilliantly and so convincingly that you can't help feel a slither of sympathy for this most wretched of humans. Ultimately, it is Scorsese's genius for subtle yet powerful story-telling that makes Raging Bull a classic.

The character of Jake La Motta is brilliantly brought to life both in Scorsese's direction and De Niro's performance. De Niro underplays the role and gives the character a strong physical presence. Indeed, his performance brings a new meaning to the concept of the method; he gained weight for the later part of the film, putting the shooting schedule on hold! The subtlety in direction and performance can be viewed in the scene where Jake first confronts his brother. "Did you fuck my wife?" This accusation comes out of nowhere, but yet, throughout the narrative, we have slowly begun building to this paranoid deluded moment. Through La Motta's characterisation, we know the psychology behind his actions. He is an obsessive. Once he gets a thought in his head, that's it. He only sees what he wants to see, without reason – whether it's to do with his constant eating or what he believes to be his wife's deception.

Scorsese's characters are often in need of redemption. La Motta is a hybrid of both Charley from Mean Streets (1973), sharing his need for painful retribution, and Travis Bickle in Taxi Driver (1976), with his psychotic obsession.

Scorsese uses the camera as a subjective tool. As in Taxi Driver, slo-mo is used to convey the murky world of the streets of New York. In Raging Bull, it also helps us see events from La Motta's point of view – when his eyes first latch onto the young Vicki, for example. Michael Chapman, the film's cinematographer, is responsible for the film's stark black-white look. This style gave it an edge, especially in what can easily be argued as Raging Bull's best scene. Jack La Motta has been jailed for selling alcohol to minors. We see a single shard of light spill into an otherwise jet-black cell. Jake is alone. He has no-one left to fight. His wife has left him, his brother has gone and his boxing career is long over. And so, he begins to repeatedly punch the wall over and over, screaming, "Why? Why? Why?"

I think what one will take away from this film is the absorbing drama of the fight scenes, completely unlike that of Rocky (1976) and Rocky 2 (1979). In Rocky, we watch the film as a spectator would watch any sport. But in Raging Bull, we feel every jab and hook; we are right there in the ring with Jake. We feel his brutal punishment. Again, this is due to the fantastic photography by Michael Chapman and the Oscar-winning skills of Thelma Schoonmaker who edited the film.

This film was no doubt another personal journey for Martin Scorsese, made in the hang-over period from his previous work, New York, New York (1977). During the latter's production, Scorsese was heavily into cocaine. The film received grave criticism and caused Scorsese to fall victim to profound depression. Previously, De Niro had approached Scorsese to make the life story of Jake La Motta and Scorsese had rejected it. It was only when he saw La Motta's self-destructive side that he made a personal connection with the subject. So, armed with Mardik Martin and Paul Schrader's script, (Scorsese had previously collaborated with Martin on Mean Streets and Schrader on Taxi Driver), Scorsese set about crafting Raging Bull like this was to be his last film. A labour of love, if you will!When first released, Raging Bull was heavily criticised for its violent imagery and it was not a box office hit. However, it was nominated for a string of Oscars but only picked up two for Best Actor and Best Editing. Scorsese lost Best Director to Robert Redford for Ordinary People (1980). But which one has had a greater cultural cinematic impact? Nevertheless, Raging Bull was voted as the best film of the decade of 1980s. A repense – unsurprisingly, as this was the decade of Polished bloc-buster. Raging Bull surpasses all of them, and their kind, in every aspect of the film-making process.

The film concerns the violent and unpleasant loser Jake "The Raging Bull" LaMotta as his boxing career rises and falls and his relationships with his wife and brother deteriorate. He is violent both in the ring and out of it and his jealousy over his second wife Vickie, Cathy Moriarty, threatens to derail their relationship and his sanity. We see immediately that he is dumb and shallow but desperate to win fights and willing to take abuse in order to be a champion. We never root for him but are depressed by the complete hopelessness of his situation by the end of the film.

The most beautiful element of the film is the cinematography which nears perfection. The grittiness of the black-and-white fits the tone of the film and the scars and scratches that develop on Jake and Cathy's faces have an extra texture to them that make them look like they exist in a 1940s film, the era in which the film is set, like Champion (1949), although De Niro's facial scars are a lot more convincing than those that appear on Kirk Douglas' face. Simple shots of men arguing in the street also appear extremely beautiful, with a creamy, sharp look to each frame that is different to the usual background shots in a sports film. The boxing matches are where the cinematography really gets to shine as the blood squirting out of De Niro's face and the devastating blow of the opposing boxer's gloves differentiates this film, again, from your average sports biopic. The fights feel more visceral and Jake's trauma more painful when we have a vivid image in our minds of what has caused his suffering.

The portrayal of LaMotta also defies convention as he is not a ï¿ 1/2~flawed' character who gains redemption through a good woman or a training montage, he is a horrible monster from the beginning and we see him get punished for his action whilst those around him continue to suffer. In comparison to Rocky (1976), the other film considered the greatest boxing film of all time, which glorifies the main character and sees him fall in love with a good woman and achieve redemption through stepping away from his amoral job and working hard to chase his dreams. If anything Raging Bull causes you to fear the central character and root for those around him to leave him, the only gratifying moment in the film occurs when Vickie finally leaves him, and this makes the film feel honest in a way that Rocky feels false. Another crucial difference is the ending, in Rocky he loses the fight but we end without seeing what Rocky's life after the fight is like, in Raging Bull we see De Niro give the famous Marlon Brando monologue from On the Waterfront (1994) and we understand how destitute he is. These differences are crucial because Raging Bull sets out not wanting to glamorize the lead character but to show how the darkness inside him is his downfall, had the film conformed to clichï¿ 1/2 (C)s this effect would have been damaged.

De Niro is absolutely brilliant, not only in the moments when he gets to ham it up but also in showing a man who is just barely able to project the image of a sane individual whilst simmering with rage just below the surface. Much like Taxi Driver (1976) he makes us incredibly uncomfortable, as he lasciviously kisses two 14-year olds in a bar that he owns, and he is able to go big when it is necessary, we see him punch his wife in a horrifying scene. This was a fully deserved Best Actor win and this is a performance that makes the case for De Niro being one of the greatest actors of all time. Moriarty is sad as the beautiful young woman who becomes an abused wife and her deep voice and deadpan delivery help to normalize a terrible situation in a scarily effective way. Pesci employs his usual shtick in playing LaMotta's brother and is part of one of the best directed scenes in the film in which an enemy of the brothers has his head smashed by a taxi door. Scorsese is famed for getting great performances out of actors and although I would place Ellen Burstyn in Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore (1974) above De Niro's in this film he is still one of the all-time greats.

A masterpiece that is a superlative in terms of acting, editing, and the entire sports genre, Raging Bull represents a torrent of raw, violent masculinity under attack. One could put forth many points that this is Scorsese's magnum opus, and they wouldn't be wrong. You even could say that this film saved his career and life in the early 80s as he was recovering from coke addiction.

It tells the story of how boxer Jake La Motta nearly destroyed his life due to out of control anger issues and persistent sexual jealousy toward his wife. De Niro delivers the performance of his life (the massive weight gain is just a tiny part of it) and with Pesci to back him up, I can confidently say that no other film matches this one in terms of acting. Cathy Moriarty is also great as La Motta's victimized wife, and Frank Vincent's turn as Salvy foresees something about a shinebox. We can sympathize with Jake despite his rage and disgusting appetite, with his insecurities and frustration, with the mafia keeping the title out of his hand, while also seeing him for the repellent jerk he is.

Raging Bull is an editor's wet dream. It honestly might be the best edited film I've ever seen. The way the picture flows together seamlessly, making smart use of cuts or doing without them, adds to the technical marvel. Thelma Schoonmaker won a well deserved Oscar for her technique. The movie contains one of the greatest tracking shots of all time, in the championship title scene, as it follows La Motta from his dressing room all the way to the ring. This combined with a beautiful musical piece by composer Pietro Mascagni makes for raw emotion on steroids, and I'm not ashamed to say it made me weep. The cinematography of this film is a sight to behold thanks to Michael Chapman, who also shot Taxi Driver, and the black and white lens gives it a strange melancholy beauty.

Since redemption is a key feature of Scorsese's pictures we get an ambiguous ending here about the nature of Jake's rebirth. As he quotes Brando's famous speech from On the Waterfront, we wonder if he really does see the problems he caused or simply looking for someone else to blame.

While the film is bleak, it also has a tendency to be very funny at times. The dynamic and countless dialogue exchanges between De Niro and Pesci are comedy gold. I always burst out laughing at the scene where Jake loses his shit over a burnt steak, and again when he gets Joey to punch him in the face over and over again. And no other film could pull off a hilarious line like "your mother sucks fucking big fucking elephant dick" so well.

So in other words Raging Bull is a masterpiece and one that should be seen by everyone and seen again. A man that dies without seeing this film is not a man at all.

Raging Bull is notable because it does something I’ve rarely seen in any other film. It is a biopic that takes an entirely unfiltered and unbiased look at events in the life of Jake La Motta, trying to emulate a documentary. And by doing this it sucks all emotion from the experience. I watched without caring, and didn’t even know if I was supposed to care about anything in the movie. There is not much flow or narrative structure, instead it plays out like you’re watching a series of home movies. But not ones documenting the highlights and exciting events of life, these home movies show the depressing and awful moments. It’s hard to express how much I felt like Scorsese was intentionally keeping me away from connecting with all that is unfolding. Despite my best efforts to enjoy the experience, he kept me at arm’s length and demanded that I just watch and see what happens instead of getting emotionally involved. A big part of that feeling of distance probably comes from the fact that I could find no audience surrogate in the film. There aren’t characters that I could identify with and use as my window into the film. The main character is a broken man, who behaves in a despicable fashion the entire time. It’s easy to hate Jake La Motta, and I guess that is to Robert De Niro’s credit, because I get the impression he was an unpleasant man. Joe Pesci’s role as the brother is the closest Raging Bull comes to offering an opportunity for the audience to sympathize with someone in the story. However, he has such an abrasive personality, and doesn’t add much nuance to make his character likeable. Also, while I’m talking about the cast, in what world does Cathy Moriarty look at all like a teenager? I understand that among La Motta’s many flaws was his penchant for underage women, so why not cast someone who actually looks under 30? The boxing in Raging Bull might be some of the least convincing I’ve seen in a major motion picture. It rarely feels like the punches are connecting, or that any of these actors actually belong in a boxing ring. Also, there simply isn’t enough boxing to make that a central thrust of the film. It’s a non-stop string of things outside the ring that happened to this unpleasant person who happens to be a boxer. There’s nothing to look forward to, there’s no drama waiting to see what will come next, instead it’s like sitting through a slide show of depressing proportions. The words that instantly come to mind when I reflect on Raging Bull are things like “flat,” “bleak,” and “monotonous.” I’m willing to admit that the nearly perfect way that it repels me is a sign that something powerful is happening with the film, and therefore there must be logic to the fact that others revere it. I’m just delighted that I never have to watch it again.

This is a great film on a number of levels - as a biography of former middleweight boxing champion Jake La Motta, yes, but also a fascinating character study, with stellar performances from Robert De Niro and Joe Pesci, and epic direction from Martin Scorsese.  

The opening sequence sets the stage for something special; De Niro is dancing in place alone in the ring in poetic slow motion, we see the film will be in black and white and there is a smoky haze in the background as the opening credits roll.   We will soon see just how crazy this man is, as he turns over the dining table in a fight with his first wife over how long to cook his steak, yells down at his complaining neighbor that he's going to kill and eat his dog, and then goads his younger brother (Pesci) into punching him in the face as hard as he can.  Throughout the movie, the dialog between De Niro and Pesci is loud, confrontational, argumentative, and fantastic.  

The times were certainly different, and La Motta was part blunt New Yorker and part Cro-Magnon.  He makes out with his wife on the floor in front of his sister-in-law and their toddlers.  He's insanely jealous, and accuses his brother of having had sex with his wife (lines I will never forget, and sometimes quote: "I heard things Joey, I heard things" ... "What things you heard?" ... "I heard some things").  After confronting his wife, she "confesses" out of frustration, so he marches over to his brother's house and beats him up, also punching his wife in the face in the process, all in front of his brother's stunned kids.  

La Motta met his second wife Vikki when she was just 15, and married her when she was 16.  In the film she's played well by Cathy Moriarty, though she seems much older (she was only 20 at the time though).  In another unforgettable scene, this one erotically charged, she kisses his body when he's not allowed to have sex before a fight, and then after he goes to the sink to pour ice water down his shorts to cool off, shows up in the mirror and begins kissing him some more.  Scorsese uses a perfect amount of restraint here, however, and we never 'see' anything.   

Unfortunately, he doesn't apply this same restraint to violence in the right, overstating it considerably, even considering the type of fighter La Motta was.  We see blood spraying as if it were out of a hose, and boxers enduring more punishment than humanly possible.   Maybe this is how Scorsese the man saw boxing, having not been a fan beforehand, or Scorsese the artist preferred to paint the violence of the men involved in the sport.  Regardless, it was not necessary.  That said, seeing De Niro at the end of the last bout with Sugar Ray Robinson (Johnny Barnes), his face a meatloaf, eyes puffed over but grinning like a ghoul as he tottered over to Sugar Ray, taunting him despite the beating he just took, saying "ya never got me down Ray", is another memorable moment.

Cut to 6 years later, a fat La Motta is poolside in Florida smoking a cigar, having retired.  The legend is that De Niro gained 60-70 pounds over 4 months by eating high-end food in France and Italy, and it's just another larger-than-life aspect of this movie.  It's painful to watch his awkward stand-up act, his crude jokes, his philandering with women in the bar, and getting thrown into jail for having let young teenagers into his bar (they having 'proved' being of legal age by French kissing him).  His beer belly hangs out of his shirt while he's in a pay phone.  Like an idiot, he hammers the jewels out of his championship belt, looking to pawn them, and not understanding they're worth far more in the belt.  He's estranged from his brother, and the scene with De Niro following Pesci out of a convenience store down the street is heart wrenching.

The film ends with De Niro quoting Brando in 'On the Waterfront' as he practices his stand-up act in front of a mirror.  He does it with just the right amount of poor delivery (he's acting as La Motta after all) and pathos, it's another great scene, but I have to say, the words themselves ring false - La Motta's brother WAS looking out for him, among other things beating the hell out of some guys in a nightclub when they were getting too close to his wife, and La Motta did NOT end up with a one-way ticket to Palookaville after throwing a fight for the mafia, he ended up with a title fight a couple of years later and won it.  

Scorsese may have included too much violence, but he does so many other brilliant things.   Black and white was an excellent choice.  He uses slow motion to create an epic feel to moments.  He uses stills of some of the boxing victories, and footage altered to appear as if it's from old home movies to show events in some of the intervening years.    He tells the story with brutal honesty.   Most of all, he gives outstanding actors freedom, and they really delivered.

Boxing legend Jake La Motta had possibly one of the sternest chins in the history of the sport, but his hothead personality overshadowed his career in the ring, and marred his life outside of it. Standing at 5ft 8in, La Motta may not have been a commanding presence, but out of the 106 total fights he featured in, 83 of them were wins, 4 were draws and 19 of them losses. And most of time, whenever he lost a match it was either down to his self-destructive behaviour, purposeful abandonments, mafia restrictions or boxer favouritism. La Motta had a remarkable career, but his destructive personality and its effects on his life made his existence a tragedy, and Martin Scorseseâ??s cinematic take on his career, Raging Bull, a dramatic feast.
 
Raging Bull finds Scorsese and De Niro midway into their cinematic affiliation, proving to be a successful duo even when making a sport movie, one which ranks right at the top with Sylvester Stalloneâ??s Rocky. On a lesser note, De Niro and Stallone made another boxing film together, Grudge Match, which saw the two legends re-enter the ring, albeit to laughs rather than Oscars.
 
Having found the project and convinced Scorsese to direct it, Robert De Niro chose to play Jake La Motta, and boy did his persistence pay off. De Niro is a shadow of his real self, and I say that as a compliment, because even though we know De Niro to be great in nearly all of his films, his only Oscar winning performance will leave you speechless with awe at how marvellous a character he has created. De Niro put on the muscle, learned to box, and even put on tonnes of make up to mould his damaged and ever transforming nose, cheeks and tough chin, but his greatest achievement is gaining 27kg to portray an older, much more rotund La Motta. His raw, unrelenting persona never breaks stride, even in the face of family, producing a character that drives the story and everything else around it, including the audience. De Niroâ??s passion for the project it appears has paid off for without his central performance, Raging Bull would never have become great.
 
And as De Niro produces a character that dominates the proceedings, the film is played out through the many relationships La Motta destroys. Jake and Joeyâ??s relationship is perhaps most important to Jake, and the one that reveals his true character both at his lowest and highest points of humanity. When Jake turns on his brother, Raging Bull is at its most riveting, and Jakeâ??s life at its most embarrassing, but when he measly attempts to make up with his brother after a long period, we feel his humanity sky-rocketing, and want to help him get across what he has never been able to do before in his life â?? appreciate another human. Joey is the key to Jakeâ??s transformation, but the inability for any character to understand this is the true tragedy of the tale.
 
Jakesâ?? first wifeâ??s inability to cook food rapidly shows just how angry Jake can get over nothing; it is a precursor of what is to come. So you feel for his second wife, Vikki, when she pops along and is completely smitten with Jake. Our inability to warn Vikki of Jakeâ??s temperament draws us in to the point where we fear what Jake could do to her, and that is testament to De Niro once again who breeds life into Jake, where the demons that dictate his personality are brought to the forefront of our awareness. Even as a boxer he is respected by his opponents for his tough, never say die attitude, but this same attitude finds him a loner in the boxing industry. Destroying a young boxer, after Vikki compliments his looks, with no signs or restraint or remorse, we see this story becoming a quest to unravel the many layers that make up Jake La Mottaâ??s mind-set. Paranoia and jealousy are just a few traits corrupting his soul, but what is most revealing is that La Motta does not have the capacity to realise his destructive behaviour, and that is tragic because he is constantly thinking of others and cannot even understand himself.
 
Raging Bull then is very much a stark, no holds-barred investigation of a manâ??s mental processes who also happens to be a hothead boxer with a tough chin. And that tough chin is significant both in and out of the ring for he could never stop himself from doing it the La Motta way, and failing to understand anything else other than his narrow-minded perception which always produced fireworks, and in turn ruined his social relations that bit more. His self-destructive personality is driven by an animalistic enthusiasm, obsessive rage, sexual envy and relationship-wrecking distrust. These features of his personality constitute a detrimental lifestyle that deteriorates even further before our eyes and believe it or not never gets better. Scorsese masterfully makes us feel this ruin non-stop, never providing our protagonist with marks of humanity, yet we canâ??t help but sympathise with our protagonist and hope one day he can change.
 
Martin Scorsese is said to not be a fan of sport in general, let alone boxing in particular, yet the way in which he has used the camera to heighten La Mottaâ??s personality and the combative atmosphere should be marvelled at as the work of someone who knows the sport inside out. Raging Bull has been executed in a way that involves you deeper within the mentality of our protagonist. La Mottaâ??s way of seeing things is the way the camera sees things, and so for two hours we are catapulted into the mentality of a raging bull who is always on edge. The black and white look could be a barrier for the audience to get deep into the confines of La Mottaâ??s mind, but it is the complete opposite as it lures us deeper in, showing us the bare, sad existence of our protagonistâ??s mind who sees things plain and clearly but cannot come to terms with the simplicity of life. Instead he makes everything harder on himself and essentially pushes those closest to him away. It truly is a tragic plight in a life that could have had everything.
 
Amazingly, Jake La Motta is still alive today at 94 years old, proving heâ??s still got a tough chin, even against death. With Raging Bull, La Motta will always be remembered for mostly bad reasons, but that still isnâ??t enough to sway us towards hatred for our indecisiveness towards whether we like La Motta makes the character a cinematic legend, and Raging Bull a classic the entire world should see.
 
The Verdict:

In 1976 Martin Scorsese teamed up with Robert De Niro and screenwriter Paul Schrader to deliver what in my opinion is one of his best films: Taxi Driver. That year that complex character study lost out on the Oscar to Stallone's Rocky. So what does Scorsese do next? He directs a real boxing movie with another memorable and complex character played by Robert De Niro making Rocky look like a cartoon character. Don't get me wrong, I loved Rocky, but Jake La Motta is a character that feels much more authentic. He's deeply flawed and unpleasant to be around with, but his violent temper is what made him such a successful boxer on the ring. It was actually Robert De Niro who approached Scorsese to make this film based on Jake La Motta's autobiographical book and despite hesitating to make a sports movie at first, he ended up directing what is considered by many to be the best boxing film of all time. The boxing scenes are violent and bloody, but what was most surprising for me was the way in which De Niro captured the rage and paranoia of his character off the ring. La Motta isn't a very sympathetic character and his anger and jealous outbursts led him to his ultimate downfall, but somehow there is still something redeeming about him and De Niro captured that essence perfectly in this Award winning performance. It's much more a character study than a boxing film, but Scorsese also explores Jake La Motta's bond with his brother Joey turning this into a sibling relationship study as well. Jake tries to channel his rage through boxing, but ultimately it defeats him outside of the ring destroying the relationships he has formed. Near the end there is a nice nod to Brando's On the Waterfront, which was a perfect touch by Scorsese who seems to always be in control of his craft and at the same time honoring other famous films. Raging Bull is an artistic film dealing with a difficult subject matter but it still is considered by many as the best film from the 80's. It's a near masterpiece in my opinion with another outstanding lead performance by De Niro, who was without a doubt the best actor at that time. 

Jake La Motta (Robert De Niro) is the raging bull who during the 40's dominated every rival inside the ring. No one could take hits like he did and despite losing a couple fights he took pride in the fact that he never went down.  Jake's brother, Joey (Joe Pesci) is his sparring partner and at the same time he manages his fights so they have a very close relationship. Joey has a few connections with the mob, but Jake refuses to deal with them and wants to get a chance at the title on his own. Joey also introduces him to a fifteen year old girl named Vickie (Cathy Moriarty), whom he later marries. As the years go by, Jake defeats his opponents but the title shot keeps eluding him since he refuses to work with the mob despite Joey's connection with Salvy Batts (Frank Vincent). While Jake's professional boxing career begins to take off, his personal life takes a blow when he allows his jealousy and paranoia to take over as he fears his wife is seeing other men. Despite channeling his rage in the ring, he also takes it out in his home on his wife and brother. What at first served as his inspiration for becoming a boxing champion escalated so much that it also became his downfall and ruin. Raging Bull centers on Jake's self destructive boxing journey and it is a very complex and emotional one. In the midst of it all there is still a redemptive quality to this antihero and he accepts his punishment through personal beatings in the ring.

Martin Scorcese's adaptation of a boxer's autobiography also contains content adapted (or, less generously, plagiarized) from previous films. The elements of the book that Scorcese emphasizes are the same that were at the core of "Rocky," and it is therefore fair to draw comparisons between the two: an Italian-American boxer who fights an African-American boxer and loses, an overshadowed wife figure, and a short, pudgy brother figure who doubles as a manager. What Scorcese's film does not have is any of the heart and sweetness that made "Rocky" enjoyable. Perhaps he hoped to replace the sweetness and light with a more realistic, hardcore sentiment, but he got only as far as the blood and gore and cursing, and forgot to add any meaning. There are no stakes to Jake LaMotta (Robert DeNiro)'s fights, as there were for Rocky's: Jake's life winds up the same regardless of their outcome. It's difficult to find a reason to care whether he wins or loses, unless you're content to root for him because he's the main character. "Rocky" knew that wasn't a good enough reason, and fleshed out its characters and world. If there were no elements of LaMotta's book that could have given some originality and depth to the story, Scorcese should have invented some.

Instead of filling in the story's sizable gaps with original content, Scorcese rips off "The Godfather" in completely needless, bizarrely particular ways. There are grainy pictures at a wedding party where everyone is wearing the exact clothes from the beginning of Coppola's movie, and one character even reaches over to bring a woman in a red dress and wide-brimmed hat into the shot. Why import this familiar scene, stripping it of the layers of meaning it enjoyed in its original context? It adds nothing to "Raging Bull," not even the reflected luster of the superior film being copied. Later, during one of many interminable and repetitive domestic abuse scenes, a man chases his wife into a bathroom through a narrow, mirrored side-door. The door swings mostly shut, but he throws it open again. Some of the angles are the same as in that famous, far more important and meaningful scene from "The Godfather." Why such meticulous thievery? Again, it adds nothing to "Raging Bull," but it does serve to remind me of a movie I'd rather be watching, and it causes me to marvel again at the delicate plotting and characterizations that made it work in its native setting.

Near the end, LaMotta deadpans a scene from "On the Waterfront." The audacity. The conceit. Clearly, we're being asked to marvel at how true the words are of LaMotta's life (well, of course they are, the movie has been written that way, and being based on LaMotta's autobiography is no excuse), but I'm not sure what we're supposed to feel during this scene. Are we supposed to feel sad for this wretched stereotype we've spent over two hours with? Are we supposed to take pleasure in the pathetic turn his life has taken? Never having been given a reason to care about anyone or anything on screen, I feel nothing either way. It's simply a bore to watch. There is one thing to be sad about, and that's that DeNiro's career has become uncomfortably like LaMotta's: he, too, has lately been reduced to lazily reading scripts for cash.

Scorcese fans, and there are many of them who know far more about movies than I do, will say what they will about Sorcese's technical chops as a filmmaker and his fluency in the history and language of cinema. It seems inexplicable to me that so few critics saw the same "Raging Bull" that Pauline Kael saw, about which she wrote, "Scorsese's excesses verge on self-parody. You can feel the director sweating for greatness, but there's nothing under the scenes... De Niro's portrayal of La Motta is a swollen puppet with only bits and pieces of a character inside." That describes the "Raging Bull" I watched. Without a story to put Scorcese's talents in service of, they're wasted. "Raging Bull" is preening and shallow, and every element in it was done better before and since by filmmakers who understand the primacy of narrative.

Has there ever been a more concise metaphor for America than a boxer, prioritizing strength above all, idealizing crushing masculinity, pulverizing anyone who gets in its way?

Masculinity is inherently dramatic due to its fundamentally flawed nature; it's built on a rejection of the other, primitivism, insecurity, and fragility. Watching these foundational elements seep through the cracks in its hardened outer shell of repressed human emotion and bravado will always be fascinating to watch on both a psychological and visceral level, particularly for American audiences for which masculinity forms the backbone of their societal ideology. Scorsese's Raging Bull, like his exemplary Taxi Driver, is about this masculinity that pervades every aspect of American life. His "heroes" are horrible, abusive people, ignorant and violent, and yet because they're so clearly trapped in the destructive cycle of their nation's misguided social structure we feel for them when they destroy themselves. Watching this evisceration of our elemental makeup is gloriously cinematic and timeless in its effect, Scorsese getting to the heart of what plagues society at large; in doing so, he has created a masterpiece.

Good ol fashion boxing back in the day. In 1964 we meet a bloated looking LaMotta practicing his words in the dressing room before he goes out to entertain the people of a club. What follows on from there is a look at LaMotta's life his relationship with his brother Joey who is also his manager and his relationship with Vickie who he's attracted to despite already being married. The constant theme of Raging Bull is LaMotta's destructive tendencies both in and outside of the ring. Outside we watch him become paranoid that Vickie is cheating on him this then leads to violent outbursts both physically beating Vickie and also Joey. But we also see his destructive power in the ring as well, purposefully disfiguring another boxer because Vickie had mentioned he was good looking and in doing so provoking LaMotta's jealousy.



Martin Scorsese never really glorifies LaMotta and bravely delivers one of the most truthful in depth biopics you will ever see. You get a very clear picture of how violent LaMotta could be both inside and out of the ring. But while never glorifying LaMotta Scorsese also gives us a picture of a boxer with great heart. The scenes in the ring are fearsome with destructive power as we watch him destroy his opponents, taking the punches and then exploding in their faces. Speaking of the boxing scenes there is no denying that Scorsese gets across the destructive power and when you see blood spurt from a face following a punch it grabs your complete attention you may even oooh and ahhh. The boxing scenes are like art, beautifully constructed so you can feel the atmosphere, the smoke from the crowds, the steam rising off of bodies as blood drips from wounds all the time delivering the ferocity of punches flying straight at you in a tirade of quick blows. Scorsese has basically constructed some of the best boxing scenes you will ever watch, stylish, atmospheric and brutal.



Raging Bull has three stars Joe Pesci as Joey LaMotta, Cathy Moriarty as Vickie LaMotta and Robert De Niro as Jake LaMotta. Both Joe and Cathy deliver top performances in my opinion, with Joe himself shedding the pounds to play the role it is Robert De Niro's selfless performance which makes it great. There is of course the physical side, the fact in the scenes which take us back to the early 1940's he looks young and lean in peak shape, but then he piles on the pounds like around 60 pounds in weight to play LaMotta when he retired and just the realism of De Niro's body looking bloated makes it convincing. Then there is the depth of character, the anger and the paranoia, the ability to suddenly snap which he also gets across which is so impressive. It is such a full on performance from De Niro that it never feels like you are watching an actor but a man whose own self destructive nature will be his ultimate downfall.



Raging Bull is easily one of  the greatest boxing movies ever made. You could also go as far as saying it is one of the great biopics because it's truly in depth, not the pretty storylines which usually dominate the biopic genre. As such it may not be what you expect, but it will impress and leave you with plenty of memories, be it De Niro's performance or the stunning cinematography all in classic black and white.
